string_table.name: npxnabnsnfns00001001101
string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="To access your HCC email, visit the HCC homepage (howardcc.edu) and click Tools & Resources. Then click Email. You will then be prompted to enter your HCC username and password. This will open your HCC email in the Outlook Web App (OWA).
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="To compose a new email, click the New Email button. In the To field, type the email address of the person you would like to email.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If you are not familiar with their email address, click To to open a search window. Type the name of the individual in the Search people field and click the magnifying glass icon or press ENTER on your keyboard to search for them. A list of all the individuals whose names match the name criteria you searched will appear, and you can add them to your email by double-clicking on their name or single-clicking the plus button to the right of their name. When you are finished adding individuals, click OK to return to the email.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If you select the wrong individual, click in the To field and press the BACKSPACE button on your keyboard to remove them.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="After you have added your email recipients, click on the Subject field to add a subject for your email.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="To compose the body of your email, click in the blank area. Type your desired email and format if you desire.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When you are finished, click the SEND button to send your email." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="To access your Canvas Inbox, log into Canvas and click the Inbox icon on the left navigation menu. This menu is available no matter which course you are currently viewing. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You will now see your Canvas Inbox and any messages you have received from your instructors or other students. Click on a message to view the full message. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="To send a new message to your instructor, click the Compose a new message button. This will cause the Compose Message pop up window to appear. First select a course by clicking the drop down arrow in the Course field and selecting the course from the list. In the To field, begin typing in your instructor’s name and select it from the list. Alternatively, you can click on the Contacts button to the right of the To field, select Teachers from the list and select your instructor’s name. Now type in a subject for your message in the subject field. This allows your instructor to quickly understand what your message is about so if you want to ask about your grade, you can type “Grade for Exam 2”. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Now click in the white space below and type your message to your instructor. When you’re finished typing out your message, click Send to send the message to your instructor. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When your instructor replies to your message, you will see a notification on the Inbox button and you will see their message at the top of your inbox. To reply to a message, click on the message to select it and then click the Reply button. Your course, to and subject fields will automatically be filled out and you can simply click in the white space below to type your reply. When you’re finished, click Send to send the reply. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Remember: Communicating with your instructor via Canvas inbox is quick and convenient, but the rules for professional communication still apply here. Make sure you include a Subject, complete sentences and proofread before sending your message.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Email is a form of asynchronous communication which means that you and the person you are emailing may communicate with each other at any time. That doesn’t interfere with your messages being passed back and forth. Zoom or other web-conferencing tools are used by instructors at HCC for online, face-to-face synchronous meetings- which means that everyone involved is in the online environment at the same time.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Zoom is a free web-app that uses your web cam, if you have one, and microphone so that you can be seen and heard while also seeing and hearing others. Zoom also has a chat feature, which some instructors use if their students do not have microphones or they are hosting a large group online.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You can join a Zoom online meeting from your computer, tablet or SmartPhone using wifi or data.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Here’s how to join a Zoom meeting. You’ll need to click the link that will be provided in an email or posted in your Canvas site. BEFORE, you join the meeting, follow these tips:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Pick a quiet spot to sit so that you can hear and also speak without background noise.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Logout of any email or social media apps that might send you notifications (this reduces the chance that you’ll get audible notifications that can disrupt your Zoom meeting)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If you will appear on video, dress appropriately for the occasion. School clothes for a class meeting or office hours.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If you will appear on video, let others in your current space know that you are on a Zoom call and that you’ll be on video. This will reduce the chance of someone walking into your shot unintentionally.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Once you’re setup, you’re ready to click the link and launch Zoom.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click NEXT to view a video on how to join a Zoom meeting. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>
